MOSQUE BUILDING PROGRAMME
(Progress)


    2. Mr Abdullah Tarmugi asked the Minister for the Environment what is the progress of phase two of the mosque building programme and what are the expected completion dates for the remaining mosques in this phase.

     The Minister for the Environment (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Speaker, Sir, nine mosques are scheduled to be built under Phase 11 of the Mosque Building Programme of the Majlis Ugama Islam Singapura (MUIS).

    The first mosque under the Programme, Masjid En-Naeem in Hougang, was completed in November 1983. Masjid Darul Aman in Kampong Ubi is under construction and is expected to be completed in December this year. Construction work on the third mosque, Masjid Darul Makmur in Yishun, will commence soon. Tenders for the construction of Masjid Al-Mukminin in Jurong East were called in December last year and work is expected to start by the middle of this year. Tenders for two other mosques, Masjid Al-Amin in Telok Blangah/Radin Mas and Masjid Darussalam in Clementi/West Coast will be called later this year. Work on the design of these two mosques is being done now by the HDB architects.

    Tenders for Masjid Darul Ghufran in Tampines and a mosque at Jalan Sempadan in Siglap are expected to be called

Column: 1438

next year, while tenders for the construction of the ninth mosque under the Programme, ie Masjid Ar-Raudhah in Bukit Batok, will be called in early 1987.

    Sir, barring unforeseen circumstances, the construction of each of these mosques will take between 18 and 24 months to complete.

     Encik Ibrahim Othman (Tanah Merah): Sir, in view of the construction of a mosque in Jalan Sempadan, can the Minister inform the House whether MUIS has any plans for the Al-Taqwa Mosque in Jalan Bilal, Bedok?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Speaker, Sir, MUIS has no plans for the Al-Taqwa Mosque at Jalan Bilal, and MUIS is not aware of any public scheme which will affect the site on which the mosque stands.

     Encik Zulkifli bin Mohammed (Eunos): Mr Speaker, Sir, I understand there is a piece of land pledged for the building of a mosque to replace the Masjid Alkaff in Jalan Eunos in Bedok Reservoir. Can the Minister confirm that this is so and give an assurance that Masjid Alkaff will not be demolished until the construction and completion of the alternative mosque?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Speaker, Sir, a site at the junction of Bedok Reservoir Road and Bedok North Road has been safeguarded for the construction of a mosque to replace Masjid Alkaff which is affected by the redevelopment of Kampong Melayu/Kaki Bukit area. This assurance was made in this House some three years ago by the Minister for National Development himself.

    But I would like to stress, Sir, that as MUIS is heavily committed to the building of the nine mosques under Phase 11 of its Mosque Building Programme, development of the mosque at the Bedok Reservoir site can only be considered thereafter. The Member for Eunos wants an assurance to be given that the Masjid Alkaff mosque will not be demolished until the new mosque is built. This is the undertaking given by the Minister for National Development.

     The Minister for Finance, Minister for Education and Minister for Health (Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam): Mr Speaker, Sir, I just want to take this opportunity to clarify the case brought up by the Member for Whampoa at yesterday's sitting concerning the Polytechnic graduate, now in national service, who applied to the Nanyang Technological Institute (NTI) for admission and was informed, according to him, that NTI could not reserve a place for him, as is the case with those students who have been accepted for admission at the National University of Singapore.

    Sir, I made inquiries into this case and found that actually the student has not been offered a place at NTI. What happened was that after he had finished his course at the Polytechnic and was enlisted for national service, he applied to NTI but NTI had informed him that he would have to finish his National Service first and then preferably work for one or two years before he could be considered for admission to NTI.

    Sir, I would like to explain very briefly why NTI has adopted this policy. The Polytechnics were set up to train technicians who form a very important part of our industrial workforce and the Technician Diplomas of the Polytechnics are valuable tertiary qualifications in their own right. If the student had wanted all the time to take an Engineering degree at the NUS or at the NTI, then he should have gone through pre-university first and then proceeded to the NUS, and subsequently to the NTI after finishing his national service.

Column: 1440

By first going to the Polytechnic and then, having qualified from the Polytechnic, going to the NTI, the student, Sir, would actually have taken two places - one at the Polytechnic and one at NTI. This would mean that, in effect, the student would have deprived another Singaporean student of the opportunity to obtain a tertiary qualification. I think this is not desirable.

    Sir, the purpose of NTI admitting a limited number of Polytechnic graduates who already have working experience is to enable these Polytechnic graduates to interact with the students who are admitted to NTI after they have finished the first year of the Engineering course at the National University of Singapore. The Engineering courses at the NTI are practice-oriented courses, and NTI believes it is desirable to have at any one time a small number of students from the Polytechnic but they must have been working for one or two years.

    Sir, to avoid further confusion in this matter, I would like to explain that NTI's priority for admission is as follows:

    First priority will be given to those students who have finished the first year in the Engineering course at the National University of Singapore.

    Second priority will be given to graduates from our Polytechnics who have at least one or preferably two years of working experience.

    Third priority will be other graduates of the Polytechnics.

    Sir, I would like again to take this opportunity to urge all students who have finished their 'O' levels and who have good results and who intend to take Engineering at NUS or at NTI to go to preuniversity and after that to the NUS directly. They should not go to the Polytechnics because, if they go to the Polytechnics first and then to University, in fact, they are depriving other students from a chance of getting at least a Polytechnic qualification.

     Dr Koh Lip Lin (Nee Soon): Sir, I have got an amendment under Subhead LB-01. May I speak now?

     The Chairman: Yes.

     Dr Koh Lip Lin: Sir, I am glad that yesterday the Member for Bukit Batok and the Member for Moulmein brought up the problems of school principals. I am also happy to hear from the Minister of State that the Ministry is taking steps to make sure that we are going to have good principals for our schools. I just want to draw the Minister's attention to some statistics as contained in the book entitled "Key Education Statistics 1984" published by the Ministry of Education.

    On page 36 of the book, Table 28 gives statistics on the length of service of school principals. Of the 402 principals, 121 (30%) have fewer than four years' experience, 16 (4%) have experience between five and 19 years, 137 (34%) have experience between 20 and 29 years and 128 (32%) have experience of more than 30 years. In other words, our school principals are all old principals of 20 or more years of experience or new ones with little experience.

    It makes me wonder what happened to those appointed as principals during the past five to 19 years. The only conclusion I can draw is that it must be a very tough job for school principals. They just do not survive. The question is what will happen when the old principals retire and they will retire very soon because some of them have got more than 30 years' experience. It looks as if we are heading towards a crisis, and I am glad that the Ministry is aware of the problem. But I would like to point out that just by identifying the potential principals and giving them training may not be sufficient. The Ministry may want to review the service conditions of principals. We hear very very often complaints such as lack of incentives, lack of recognition of service, lack of support and encouragement, and also the risk of being removed from the job without warning or reasons given, etc. So I hope the Ministry can look at the service conditions of principals and that sufficient incentives, encouragement and support must be given to the principals.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am sorry. I did not realize that the Member had not finished yesterday. I am sorry.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, under this amendment that I moved, I wish to raise four matters and I hope I can finish them within the 10 minutes.

    First is the standard of English in our schools. And when I say "standard", I mean the appallingly low standard of English. I was told that it was not possible because it would cost the Ministry $1,300 to analyse and publish the information required. Well, I was surprised at that. I do not think any attempt is being made even this year to analyse the passes in English at 'O' level and to see what percentage of passes there are.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not think it will be disputed that the standard of English has fallen very low. I have practical -

    The Minister of State for Education and Communications and Information (Dr Tay Eng Soon): Sir, can I just touch on the point that the Member has just brought up which is not quite true?

    He said that we do not publish the results of English Language. In fact, we publish the results of the English Language for 'O' level every year. What he was referring to was a peculiar request that he made last year to have the percentage of students who passed in English, Mathematics and Second Language. And to my knowledge, Sir, I do not think the Member has actually requested the Ministry for this particular set of results.

Column: 1443



     Mr Jeyaretnam: Well, I was not aware that the percentage of passes in English was published. Was there?

    Now, to return to my subject about the standard of English I am going to relate my personal knowledge of this because last Thursday, Mr Speaker, Sir, I took my class in English in my Constituency. I am providing classes for Primary 6 students. And may I say that I was amazed to see how weak they were in English, both written and spoken English, What I would like to know from the Ministry is this: what is the Ministry doing about this very poor standard of English? I was talking to a University lecturer some days ago and he said that it is not just in Primary 6 but even in students who came into the University; their English was not up to standard. Well, I would like to know from the Ministry what steps are being taken to improve the standard of English.

    Secondly about the ruling that was made last year to prevent girls from doing technical studies in Secondary 1 and Secondary 2. This has caused unhappiness, I understand, among a number of families. May I point out, Mr Speaker, Sir, that this is discrimination under our Constitution which says that there shall be equal opportunities regardless of sex. Now, the Ministry's reply, I see, was that boys would also have to do Home Economics soon enough, and they wanted girls to do Home Economics first, making it compulsory for them. The reply misses the whole point of the letter of complaint which is: why should girls be prevented from doing technical studies in Secondary 1 and Secondary 2 if they wish to? We are told time and time again about the importance of technology and technical studies and, here, the Government is deliberately excluding girls from doing technical studies. The reply from the Ministry was that they can nevertheless do it at Secondary 3 and Secondary 4. 1 am told that that is no answer because if you have missed two years of technical studies, it would make it almost impossible to take it up at Secondary 3. So may I ask why is this discrimination inflicted on our girls? It is, of course, one suspects, part of the whole eugenics programme. It was introduced after the Great Marriage Debate began.

Column: 1444



    Now, the third point that I wish to raise under this subhead is the question of foreign students in the University. May I say that I thought the Minister for Education's response to the complaint from the Polytechnic students was more than harsh. May I tell him that the students have a right to know the reason for the increase in the fees. You cannot deny them of that right, and you should explain the reasons. The Minister was talking about the students being a privileged lot. May I remind him that in some countries, Australia comes to my mind immediately, university education is fully subsidized for Australian students. So it is nothing new about subsidizing completely the cost of University education for citizens. But my complaint really is the cost of subsidy of the foreign students in our University. I asked about the number of foreign students in the University last year, and I was told there was quite a number of them in the University. I understand there are now about one foreign student to five students in the University.

    Yesterday we were fortunate that the Minister for Education presented us with the fees and the subsidies, and he said that foreign students paid 50% more than the fees paid by Singapore students. That would mean that a foreign student studying Medicine only paid 3.76% of the recurrent cost for the study, and a foreign student doing Accountancy and Business Administration only paid 16.8%. May I know why are we subsidizing foreign students to that amount? In Australia, I am told, foreign students have to pay 25% of the cost, and there is a move to increase it now to 45%.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, there is a general feeling in Singapore that foreigners are getting away with lots of things that Singaporeans can't. I mentioned this with regard to their liability for National Service. Now there is the question of jobs and places in the universities. Why are we paying for foreign students at the expense of our own students? May I know what is the reason for this? It would appear that they were even invited to go on the SDU course free of charge. We should correct this imbalance between our students and foreign students.

Column: 1445



    Another point, Mr Speaker, Sir, is the request that was made by a parent about the insistence that anyone admitt2to the University must pass the Second Language at 'A' level before he can be awarded his degree. I am told, the problem in this particular case arises because the son, although he has got a pass in 'O' level in Second Language, did not get a pass in the 'A' level in the Second Language. The father is very worried that his son may not be awarded his degree unless he passes the Second Language at 'A' level. May I know what is the reason for this? If the boy has already got his Second Language at 'O' level, why should he be deprived of his degree because he cannot get through the Second Language at 'A' level?

    Finally, may I just reply to the hon. Member for Serangoon Gardens who was replying to the Member for Potong Pasir about muzzling University students. Perhaps he has forgotten that last year when the Political Association brought out a paper, they were told they could not publish it, and it was handed over to the Students' Union. Well, if that is not muzzling student activity, I would like to know what is?

    The Minister of State for Defence and Trade and Industry (BG Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have an amendment under Subhead LE-01. As it concerns the University and this has been raised by the Member for Anson, perhaps I will speak now.

    I would like the Minister for Education to confirm that it is in fact the policy of this Government to educate all our citizens to their maximum potential. We have stated this many times. We have explained this in this House, but perhaps it has not been fully understood, and should be stated again, I say this particularly in view of the suggestion yesterday from the Member for Potong Pasir that we could get more university graduates in Singapore simply by having a second university, and then we would automatically double the number of graduates and the amount of talent available. And the suggestion today from the Member for Anson, that because we have foreign students in the University, therefore Singaporeans are deprived of places.

Column: 1446



    These are pernicious simplifications, distortions of complex realities, of real constraints which we face. Our policy, as the Government, is that we will have enough university places for all Singaporeans who are able to go to University. In other words, if you do well enough in 'A' levels, if your results show that you are likely to benefit from a university education, then indeed you will get a university education. Not only because you deserve it, but also because, from the point of view of human investment, it is well worth our while to put in the $10,000 per year for four years, or $50,000 per year for five years in the case of doctors, to obtain a citizen better trained, better rounded, better able to contribute to the society which he belongs to.

    Our problem is not that there are not enough university places. Our problem is that there are not enough students who are deserving of university places to take up all the places available in the University. We have no difficulty arranging for further places. We have no difficulty finding jobs for the graduates when they come out and enter the economy. The fact that our starting graduates' salaries in Singapore are very much higher than starting graduates' salaries even in Japan proves that, in fact, the economy could do with very many more graduates than we now have available.

    Of course, not all graduates are in equal demand, and if all our students wish to study courses with no practical use, then we would indeed have a graduate employment problem, as has happened, I think, in Sri Lanka, where instead of producing engineers and doctors, they produce large numbers of experts in English Literature. Well, we also need experts in English Literature but I would be very sad to see 2,000 of them looking for jobs every year. So we will find places, and there are places for as many graduates as we are able to produce.

    Our problem is not to get some more places in the University. Our problem is to get more people who are fit to go to University. And the way to get more

Column: 1447

people who are fit to go to University is not to set up a second institution. We used to have a second institution. I think many Members will remember that, and some Members indeed graduated from Nanyang University. But the way to do it is to increase the pool of 'A' level students, raise the standard of students leaving school, and make more people prepared to reach university and to benefit from a university education. That is what streaming is about, that is what spending more years in school is about, that is what our junior colleges and pre-university centres are trying to do. And if we look at the numbers year by year, we will see that, in fact, each year a larger proportion of our 18-year olds have been going to university.

    The foreign students do not displace Singaporeans. But the Member for Anson speaks as if every foreign student there is depriving a Singaporean of a place. It is not so. It is not so because we have places for everybody. It is not out of largesse or out of a sense of generosity and humanity that we give places away to foreign students. Each foreign student is a worthwhile investment because when he comes, he brings ability, he brings talent. He learns in the University. Our students benefit from the wider exposure and from the mix of different students, students from different backgrounds, in the University. And many of the foreign students thereafter stay on and contribute to our economy, and contribute to this society.

    Far from looking at it as a way to prevent Singaporeans from having a place at the University, we should look at it as an investment which pays off in the society in Singapore. It is a way to bring people in. It is an investment which pays off. It is a way to bring people in without having even had to pay for their education for 12 years, from primary school to 'A' level. That is for free. The student comes whole. We give him four years of university education, and he is ours for a number of years.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Where is the loyalty?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: And in due course, I am sure many of them will develop

Column: 1448

loyalty, just as others who have come to Singapore from distant shores have developed loyalty.

    So the problem really is to find ways to increase the number of students at 'A' levels, to find ways to increase the number of students who are deserving of university places. And then as our economy expands, as the needs of society develop, to find ways for more of them to go to University. We shall expand our University's facilities. And then, if one university is not big enough, we shall have two. But that is very different from saying, 'Why don't we just have a second university and let us solve our problems thataway?'

    Mr Speaker, Sir, that is what I would like the Minister for Education to confirm - that these are complicated problems and not susceptible to simple-minded, simplistic, solutions.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Point of clarification, Mr Speaker, Sir. Yesterday, I said that it was the suggestion of the architect of Singapore's industrial programme, Dr Albert Winsemius, who suggested that there should have been a second university. Is the junior Minister for Defence implying that Dr Albert Winsemius does not know what he was talking about? Or is he implying that Dr Albert Winsemius was wrong in suggesting that there should be a second university in Singapore?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is far better to be the junior Minister for Defence than to be the Deputy Leader of the Opposition!

    I do not quarrel with Dr Winsemius. I merely ask whether the Member for Potong Pasir speaks because he believes it or because somebody else says it. There is reason to doubt because, not very many days ago, he said, "I believe it because the Prime Minister says so." And today he believes it because Dr Winsemius says so. What next?

     The Minister for Finance, Minister for Education and Minister for Health (Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam): Mr Speaker, Sir, when one is in Parliament, I believe one should observe the forms. One of the forms, Sir, if I may respectfully say, is that one should address Members by their

Column: 1449

correct designations, The Member for Teck Ghee is the Minister of State for Defence and Trade and Industry, and not the junior Minister for Defence.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: He is a junior Minister.

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: Perhaps the Member for Anson will point out in our Government publications where we have used the words "junior Minister"?

    Sir, let me go on to a more serious point. The Member for Teck Ghee, in response to a point made by the Member for Anson, has asked me to confirm that the admission of foreign students to the University will not limit the opportunities for Singaporean students to take up tertiary education and that, in fact, this policy of admitting a limited number of foreign students to the University is in the best interest of Singapore. Sir, I hardly need to add anything more to what the Member for Teck Ghee has already said most eloquently and, I would say, most pertinently. We do not admit foreign students into the NUS or into the NT( simply because we are a generous nation with overwhelming largesse to spread beyond our shores. In fact, I believe the Member for Anson has always criticized the fact that we are a parsimonious Government.

    But there are good reasons, Sir, why we should at all times ensure that our University student community does not become a parochial community. You see, Sir, we are a small society in Singapore. Our children, by and large, go through the same system of education. There is not the variety of experience or of backgrounds which would make for a truly university education. Sir, admitting a limited number, and I stress the words "limited number", of foreign students to the university gives our own Singapore students at the NUS and at the NTI the chance to interact with students who have grown up in different societies with different backgrounds. And in this way, Sir, I would hope that our students at the University would be able to acquire what I would regard to be a full university education, ie, not only getting the required training and getting their degrees but also learning more about life, not only about life in Singapore but

Column: 1450

also about life in countries outside Singapore.

    Sir, we are very stringent about the admission of foreign students into the NUS. For a start, only those foreign students who are significantly better in academic quality than our own students have any chance of being admitted. First preference is always given to our local students.

    Sir, I was the Vice-Chancellor of the National University of Singapore in 1980-1981. Since then, I have been the Minister in charge of the NUS and the NTI. During all these years when this policy of admitting a limited number of foreign students into the University was in force, I have not yet come across any instance when Singapore students who are qualified, whom we would regard as being able to complete their courses successfully at the NUS and at the NTI, have been refused admission. In fact, Sir, our problem, as the Member for Teck Ghee has said, is that we do not have, unfortunately, enough students of the right quality to proceed to university education.
